citeinfo.origin: University of South Florida College of Marine Science
citeinfo.title: C12 Offshore Buoy Dataset - Coastal Ocean Monitoring and Prediction System (COMPS)

descript.abstract: The University of South Florida Coastal Ocean Monitoring and Prediction System (COMPS) C12 offshore buoy is located at 27° 29.724' N and 83° 43.471' W. The parameters measured at this station are wind speed and direction, wind gusts, barometric pressure, air temperature, relative humidity, and shortwave and longwave radiation. In-water sensors measure vertical profiles of water temperature and salinity. An Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP) produces a vertical profile of current speed and direction. The data is transmitted from the station to the COMPS office at USF approximately every hour using the GOES satellite then made available on the COMPS website. Note that the only date reference for each data record is in the GOES transmission header and corresponds to transmission time. If the transmission time for data collected during the 23rd hour is after midnight, the date in the header will be one day ahead of the actual date of collection. The latest data and graphics of the data plots are available at http://comps.marine.usf.edi/C12/
descript.purpose: The University of South Florida has implemented a real-time Coastal Ocean Monitoring and Prediction System (COMPS) for West Florida. COMPS consists of an array of instrumentation both along the coast and offshore, combined with numerical circulation models, and builds upon existing in-situ measurements and modeling programs funded by various state and federal agencies. COMPS provides additional data needed for a variety of management issues, including more accurate predictions of coastal flooding by storm surge, safety and efficiency of marine navigation, search and rescue efforts, and fisheries management. COMPS also supports basic research programs.
descript.supplinf: The University of South Florida implemented COMPS in 1997 for West Florida as a State of Florida legislative initiative. The real-time and non real-time meteorological and oceanographic data collected from coastal stations and offshore buoy stations maintained by USF along the West Florida Shelf are part of the COMPS initiative. All USF-COMPS coastal stations are equipped with Aquatrak acoustic water level measurement sensors. The coastal stations also have a variety of meteorological and oceanographic sensors: RM Young anemometers for wind speed and direction, barometric pressure sensors, air temperature and realtive humidity sensors, rain gages, water temperature and conductivity sensors, fluorometers and transmissometers. Note that not all the stations have all these sensors. They are installed on each stations based on the need. COMPS buoy-mounted meteorological sensors consist of either the Coastal Environmental Systems Weatherpak 2000 system, modified to accommodate GOES telemetry, or the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute (WHOI) Improved METeorology (IMET) system, which has now evolved into the Air Sea Interaction METeorology (ASIMET) system, which is presently being manufactured by Star Engineering. The Weatherpaks measure wind speed and direction, air and water temperature, relative humidity, and barometric pressure. IMET and ASIMET measures the above parameters plus incoming short and long wave radiation and precipitation. (previous geoform was 'tabular digital data')

idinfo.useconst: Following academic courtesy standards, the COMPS Co-Directors (see Originator), the University of South Florida College of Marine Science, and the Grantor (see Data Set Credit) should be fully acknowledged in any subsequent publications in which any part of these data are used. Use of the data without completely reading and understanding the metadata is not recommended. Neither the University of South Florida, the USF College of Marine Science researchers, nor the State of Florida are responsible for the misuse of data from this database (see Distribution Liability).

cntperp.cntper: Dr. Mark E. Luther or Dr. Robert H. Weisberg

cntaddr.address: 140 7th Avenue South College of Marine Science University of South Florida

idinfo.datacred: The COMPS program is supported by the State of Florida and the University of South Florida, College of Marine Science. The buoy is maintained by the USF College of Marine Science. Dr. Mark Luther and Dr. Bob Weisberg are the Co-directors of the COMPS Program. The COMPS field program directors, COMPS data manager, and COMPS system administrator have also contributed to the dataset.
idinfo.native: The raw and de-coded data from this station is stored in SGI/Linux and PC/Windows based computers and are presently served on the internet.

attracc.attraccr: USF COMPS Offshore Buoy Stations (Meteorological and Oceanographic System Accuracy) Stations C10 - NAVY-2 (NA2) and C14 - Pasco County (CMP4) Buoys Wind Speed: +/- 0.3 m/sec or 3% Wind Direction: 5 - 7.8 Deg. Air Temperature: 0.1 deg. C (If full temperature calibration, 0.05 deg. C) Water Temperature: +/- 0.005 deg. C Barometric Pressure: 1 mbar Relative Humidity: +/- 2% RH (77 deg) Precipitation: +/- 0.4 mm per hour Shortwave Radiation: +/- 1% Longwave Radiation: +/- 1% SM MicroCAT - Conductivity and Temperature Recorder Temperature: +/-.002 deg C Conductivity: 0.003 ms/cm Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP) Velocity: +/- 0.25% of water velocity relative to ADCP +/-2.5mm/s (1200 & 600Khz) +/- 0.5% of water velocity relative to ADCP +/-5mm (300Khz) Temperature: +/- 0.4 degrees C Tilt: +/- 0.5 deg. Compass: +/- 2 degrees Staions West Florida Central (C12), West Florida South (C13) and Seacoos (C17) Buoys Wind Speed: +/- 0.3 m/sec or 3% Wind Direction: 5 - 7.8 Deg. Air Temperature: +/- 0.3 deg C Water Temperature: +/- 0.15 deg. C Barometric Pressure: .2 mbar and .5 mbar from -18 deg. C to 50 deg. C Compass: +/- 1 deg (at 25 Deg, 0 deg heel) Relative Humidity: 4% total error Shortwave Radiation: +/- 1% Longwave Radiation: +/- 1% Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP) Velocity: +/- 0.25% of water velocity relative to ADCP +/-2.5mm/s (1200 & 600Khz) +/- 0.5% of water velocity relative to ADCP +/-5mm (300Khz) 1mm/s Temperature: +/- 0.4 degrees C Tilt: +/- 0.5 deg. Compass: +/- 2 degrees

dataqual.complete: The near real-time data telemetred from the C12 offshore buoy station data can be accessed via the website http://comps.marine.usf.edu/C12/. The C12 offshore buoy Station website is updated every hour, and data for the past 24-hour in report form can be accessed via the website. Various Data Display (Time series and Wind Vector plots) plots (Past 24 hours and 5- Days) are also available for download from the website. The details of data format are also provided in the website. The data format details are also available. For further details on data availability and access, please contact COMPS Program Data Manager. The station log of maintenance, problems, and observations relevant to the Sensor systems on the stations are maintained in College of Marine Science, University of South Florida, St. Petersburg, Florida. The raw data telemetred from the station are archived at College of Marine Science, University of South Florida. The raw data will be provided based on request to the Pricipal Investigators of the USF COMPS Project.

procstep.procdesc: A brief overview of the data processing steps of USFCMS COMPS Coastal and Offshore weather monitoring data is presented here. Detailed description of the processing scripts used are available at College of Marine Science, University of South Florida. USF has two downlink systems to acquire the coastal and offshore stations data via GOES: a Digital Direct Reading Ground Station (DDRGS) and a Domestic Satellite rebroadcast receiving system (DOMSAT). We also download our data from NESDIS using Local Readout Ground Station software package obtained from NOAA, NESDIS. The hourly data streams (meteorological and water parameters) received from coastal stations consist of ten 6-minute samples. The hourly data streams (measurements of meteorological parameters) that are received from the offshore stations consist of four 15-minute and three 20-minute samples for buoys equipped with Coastal Climate WeatherPak systems and USF/ASIMET systems respectively. The ADCP (velocities, direction) consist of one sample per hour. The salinity and temperature data consist of three 20 minute samples on IMET/ASIMET type buoys and two 30 minute samples on coastal climate weatherpak buoys. Once received the data are processed using decoder scripts written in C and Perl programming languages. Observations are then served to the public via the Internet at http://comps.marine.usf.edu. These data are also available via the NDBC who have direct access for input to the National Center for Environmental Prediction for improved marine weather forecasts at http://www.ndbc.noaa.gov/Maps/Florida.shtml. The most recent observations, graphics and reports (past one and five days duration) generated from the data are available for download from the individual station web site. Development of a web based data management system is in progress.

enttyp.enttypd: The attributes in this entity describe the observations made by the instruments at the station every fifteen minutes. Column headers (attribute labels) are inserted ahead of each hourly report (three twenty-minute data records).

attr.attrdef: Water temperature in the top one meter of the water column

attrvai.attrvae: +/-2 degrees compass error. Vane accuracy is +/-0.1 degree and operates over the full 360 degrees

attr.attrdef: Wind gusts (bird 1) - maximum wind speed over a one-minute sampling period

overview.eaover: The individual environmental observations made at this station are described in the Detailed Description (section 5.1) of this metadata record. Each hour of observations (four records per hour) is preceded by a column header.
overview.eadetcit: See USF COMPS ftp server for format file (http://comps.marineusf.edu/C17/),See NOAA GOES transmitter web site for more information about transmitter operation (http://dcs.noaa.gov)

distinfo.distliab: This server (comps.marine.usf.edu) provides real-time oceanographic data to the public; however, all data are provisional and have not been quality-controlled. While all due care is taken to provide accurate information, provisional data are subject to change or retraction after quality control and before official release. No warranty is made, express or implied, regarding the accuracy or validity of the data, or regarding the suitability of the data for any particular application. This server is not an official source for these data products. For further information please contact the distributor.
